appInfo application availability catDesc catRef category change classDecl correction edition editionStmt editorialDecl encodingDesc extent fileDesc funder hyphenation idno langUsage language licence listPrefixDef namespace normalization prefixDef profileDesc projectDesc publicationStmt quotation revisionDesc segmentation sourceDesc tagUsage tagsDecl taxonomy teiHeader textClass titleStmt

elementSpec.desc: contains the whole of a TEI encoded corpus, comprising a single corpus header and one or more TEI elements, each containing a single text header and a text.

contains a single TEI-conformant document, combining a single TEI header with one or more members of the model.resource class. Multiple TEI elements may be combined within a TEI (or teiCorpus) element.

publicationStmt.p: First published as part of TEI P2, this is the P5 version using a name space.

sourceDesc.p: No source: this is an original work.

body.p: This is about the shortest TEI document imaginable.

titleStmt.title: Great Britain parliamentary corpus ParlaMint-GB, Lords, 2017-01-24
Minutes of the House of Lords, Daily Session 2017-01-24

bibl.title: UK Parliamentary Corpus. Volume 778. Tuesday 24th January 2017.

elementSpec.desc: contains a single text of any kind, whether unitary or composite, for example a poem or drama, a collection of essays, a novel, a dictionary, or a corpus sample.

body.l: Is it a dragonfly or a maple leaf
That settles softly down upon the water?

exemplum.p: The body of a text may be replaced by a group of nested texts, as in the following schematic:

elementSpec.desc: contains the whole body of a single unitary text, excluding any front or back matter.
contains a subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text.

valItem.desc: General purpose text division for all parts of parliamentary proceedings. If needed, the @subtype attribute can be used for additional content classification.

elementSpec.desc: contains a note or annotation.

valItem.desc: Description in the third person of events taking place in the meeting, e.g. "Mr X. takes the Chair".
Summaries of speeches that are individually not interesting, e.g. "Question put and agreed to".
Name, role and possible description of a person doing the speech
The location of the speaker, who was not on the podium
Date and time of the beginning and end of the debate
The presence of the members of parliament
Comments on the conduct of debates

exemplum.p: In the following example, the translator has supplied a footnote containing an explanation of the term translated as "painterly":
exemplum.egXML:
And yet it is not only in the great line of Italian renaissance art, but even in the painterly Malerisch. This word has, in the German, two distinct meanings, one objective, a quality residing in the object, the other subjective, a mode of apprehension and creation. To avoid confusion, they have been distinguished in English as picturesque and painterly respectively. style of the Dutch genre painters of the seventeenth century that drapery has this psychological significance.
translation from German to English Hottinger, Marie Donald Mackie
exemplum.p: For this example to be valid, the code MDMH must be defined elsewhere, for example by means of a responsibility statement in the associated TEI header.
The global n attribute may be used to supply the symbol or number used to mark the note's point of attachment in the source text, as in the following example:
exemplum.egXML: Mevorakh b. Saadya's mother, the matriarch of the family during the second half of the eleventh century, The alleged mention of Judah Nagid's mother in a letter from 1071 is, in fact, a reference to Judah's children; cf. above, nn. 111 and 54. is well known from Geniza documents published by Jacob Mann.
exemplum.p: However, if notes are numbered in sequence and their numbering can be reconstructed automatically by processing software, it may well be considered unnecessary to record the note numbers.

elementSpec.desc: marks any vocalized but not necessarily lexical phenomenon, for example voiced pauses, non-lexical backchannels, etc.
marks any communicative phenomenon, not necessarily vocalized, for example a gesture, frown, etc.

kinesic.desc: sign for the end of discussion

elementSpec.desc: marks any phenomenon or occurrence, not necessarily vocalized or communicative, for example incidental noises or other events affecting communication.

incident.desc: He stands and with him the whole Assembly
The Assembly observed a minute of silence. Applause.
Arrival of the President of the Republic of Poland

elementSpec.desc: indicates a point where material has been omitted in a transcription, whether for editorial reasons described in the TEI header, as part of sampling practice, or because the material is illegible, invisible, or inaudible.
contains a short description of the purpose, function, or use of its parent element, or when the parent is a documentation element, describes or defines the object being documented.

exemplum.egXML:
Example of a desc element for transcriber comments:
sounds from the chamber
...
signal for end of debate
...
minute of silence

exemplum.p: Example of a desc element used as a part of taxonomy:

exemplum.egXML:
Example of a desc to describe gaps in the transcript: ... I would further state that
speaker spoke too quietly, not understood
and furthermore ...

elementSpec.desc: contains a single-word, multi-word, or symbolic designation which is regarded as a technical term.

exemplum.egXML: A computational device that infers structure from grammatical strings of words is known as a parser, and much of the history of NLP over the last 20 years has been occupied with the design of parsers.
We may define discoursal point of view as the relationship, expressed through discourse structure, between the implied author or some other addresser, and the fiction.
We may define discoursal point of view as the relationship, expressed through discourse structure, between the implied author or some other addresser, and the fiction.
We discuss Leech's concept of discoursal point of view below.

elementSpec.desc: defines a reference to another location, possibly modified by additional text or comment.
marks the beginning of a new page in a paginated document.

exemplum.p: Page numbers may vary in different editions of a text.
A page break may be associated with a facsimile image of the page it introduces by means of the facs attribute

elementSpec.desc: contains a stretch of speech usually preceded and followed by silence or by a change of speaker.

egXML.u: well Joe and I set it between us

elementSpec.desc: represents any segmentation of text below the chunk level.

egXML.s: So father's only glory was the ballfield.

seg.seg: Sigmund, the son of Volsung, was a king in Frankish country.
Sinfiotli was the eldest of his sons ...
Borghild, Sigmund's wife, had a brother ...

elementSpec.desc: contains a sentence-like division of a text.
represents a grammatical (not necessarily orthographic) word.

exemplum.p: This example is adapted from the Folger Library’s Early Modern English Drama version of The Wits: a Comedy by William Davenant.

elementSpec.desc: contains a character or string of characters regarded as constituting a single punctuation mark.

exemplum.p: Example encoding of the German sentence Wir fahren in den Urlaub., encoded with attributes from att.linguistic discussed in section .

elementSpec.desc: defines a collection of associations or hypertextual links.
defines an association or hypertextual link among elements or passages, of some type not more precisely specifiable by other elements.

egXML.s: The state Supreme Court has refused to release Rahway State Prison inmate James Scott on bail.
The fighter is serving 30-40 years for a 1975 armed robbery conviction in the penitentiary.

elementSpec.desc: contains a proper noun or noun phrase.
contains a number, written in any form.

egXML.p: I reached twenty-one on my twenty-first birthday
Light travels at 3×1010 cm per second.

elementSpec.desc: contains a date in any format.

exemplum.p: The element date gives the date of the release, where the when gives the date in the ISO 8601 format, while the textual content can give it according to the conventions used in the local language:

elementSpec.desc: contains a phrase defining a time of day in any format.

exemplum.egXML: As he sat smiling, the quarter struck — the quarter to twelve.

elementSpec.desc: contains an email address identifying a location to which email messages can be delivered.
supplies descriptive and declarative metadata associated with a digital resource or set of resources.

titleStmt.title: Shakespeare: the first folio (1623) in electronic form
titleStmt.author: Shakespeare, William (1564–1616)

availability.p: Freely available on a non-commercial basis.

sourceDesc.bibl: The first folio of Shakespeare, prepared by Charlton Hinman (The Norton Facsimile, 1968)

projectDesc.p: Originally prepared for use in the production of a series of old-spelling concordances in 1968, this text was extensively checked and revised for use during the editing of the new Oxford Shakespeare (Wells and Taylor, 1989).

normalization.p: Original spelling and typography is retained, except that long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

cRefPattern.p:
A reference is created by assembling the following, in the reverse order as that listed here:
the n value of the preceding lb
a period
the n value of the ancestor div2
a space
the n value of the parent div1

elementSpec.desc: contains a full bibliographic description of an electronic file.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed as part of TEI P5

sourceDesc.p: No print source exists: this is an original digital text

elementSpec.desc: groups information about the title of a work and those responsible for its content.

titleStmt.title: Capgrave's Life of St. John Norbert: a machine-readable transcription

elementSpec.desc: contains a title for any kind of work.

remarks.p: Attribute is required in titleStmt context.

egXML.title: Information Technology and the Research Process: Proceedings of a conference held at Cranfield Institute of Technology, UK, 18–21 July 1989
Hardy's Tess of the D'Urbervilles: a machine readable edition

elementSpec.desc: contains the formalized descriptive title for a meeting or conference, for use in a bibliographic description for an item derived from such a meeting, or as a heading or preamble to publications emanating from it.

div.meeting: Ninth International Conference on Middle High German Textual Criticism, Aachen, June 1998.

elementSpec.desc: supplies a statement of responsibility for the intellectual content of a text, edition, recording, or series, where the specialized elements for authors, editors, etc. do not suffice or do not apply. May also be used to encode information about individuals or organizations which have played a role in the production or distribution of a bibliographic work.
contains a proper noun or proper-noun phrase referring to a person, possibly including one or more of the person's forenames, surnames, honorifics, added names, etc.

egXML.persName: Edward George Bulwer-Lytton, Baron Lytton of Knebworth

remarks.p: Special persons (like 'anonymous', 'group' etc.) have their name in term.

elementSpec.desc: contains a forename, given or baptismal name.
contains an additional name component, such as a nickname, epithet, or alias, or any other descriptive phrase used within a personal name.
contains a connecting phrase or link used within a name but not regarded as part of it, such as van der or of.
contains a name component which indicates that the referent has a particular role or position in society, such as an official title or rank.

egXML.p: The S.G. is the only national public official, including the Supreme Court justices, required by statute to be “learned in the law.”

Solicitor General Noel J. Francisco, representing the administration, asserted in rebuttal that there was nothing to disavow (...) Francisco had violated the scrupulous standard of candor about the facts and the law that S.G.s, in Republican and Democratic administrations alike, have repeatedly said they must honor.

elementSpec.desc: contains a family (inherited) name, as opposed to a given, baptismal, or nick name.
contains a phrase describing the nature of a person's intellectual responsibility, or an organization's role in the production or distribution of a work.
specifies the name of an individual, institution, or organization responsible for the funding of a project or text.

egXML.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities, an independent federal agency
Directorate General XIII of the Commission of the European Communities
The Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada

elementSpec.desc: contains an organizational name.

remarks.p: Used when "the same" party changes its name
Used when "the same" party changes its name

elementSpec.desc: groups information relating to one edition of a text.
describes the particularities of one edition of a text.
describes the approximate size of a text stored on some carrier medium or of some other object, digital or non-digital, specified in any convenient units.

exemplum.p: The measure element may be used to supply normalised or machine tractable versions of the size or sizes concerned.

elementSpec.desc: contains a word or phrase referring to some quantity of an object or commodity, usually comprising a number, a unit, and a commodity name.

exemplum.p: This example references a definition of a measurement unit declared in the TEI header:

unitDef.label: merk
unitDef.desc: A merk was an area of land determined variably by its agricultural productivity.

elementSpec.desc: groups information concerning the publication or distribution of an electronic or other text.

availability.p: This is an open access work licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license.

elementSpec.desc: provides the name of the organization responsible for the publication or distribution of a bibliographic item.
supplies any form of identifier used to identify some object, such as a bibliographic item, a person, a title, an organization, etc. in a standardized way.

remarks.p: sample values recomended to use with type="URI"

elementSpec.desc: supplies information about the availability of a text, for example any restrictions on its use or distribution, its copyright status, any licence applying to it, etc.

availability.p: Ovaj rad je dostupan pod međunarodnom licencom Creative Commons Imenovanje 4.0
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License

licence.p: The MIT License applies to this document.

elementSpec.desc: contains information about a licence or other legal agreement applicable to the text.

egXML.licence: Licence: Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 New Zealand Licence

licence.p: The Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported (CC BY 3.0) Licence applies to this document.
The licence was added on January 1, 2013.

elementSpec.desc: marks paragraphs in prose.

egXML.p: Hallgerd was outside. There is blood on your axe, she said. What have you done?
I have now arranged that you can be married a second time, replied Thjostolf.
Then you must mean that Thorvald is dead, she said.
Yes, said Thjostolf. And now you must think up some plan for me.

elementSpec.desc: describes the source(s) from which an electronic text was derived or generated, typically a bibliographic description in the case of a digitized text, or a phrase such as "born digital" for a text which has no previous existence.

sourceDesc.bibl: The Interesting story of the Children in the Wood. In Victor E Neuberg, The Penny Histories. OUP 1968.

sourceDesc.p: Born digital: no previous source exists.

elementSpec.desc: contains a loosely-structured bibliographic citation of which the sub-components may or may not be explicitly tagged.

bibl.title: Minutes of the National Assembly of the Republic of Bulgaria

elementSpec.desc: describes a set of recordings used as the basis for transcription of a spoken text.

equipment.p: Multiple close microphones mixed down to stereo Digital Audio Tape, standard play, 44.1 KHz sampling frequency

recordingStmt.p: Three distinct recordings made by hidden microphone in early February 2001.

elementSpec.desc: provides details of an audio or video recording event used as the source of a spoken text, either directly or from a public broadcast.

equipment.p: Recorded on a Sony TR444 walkman by unknown participants; remastered to digital tape at Borehamwood Studios by Transcription Services Inc.
Recorded from FM Radio to digital tape

elementSpec.desc: indicates the location of any form of external media such as an audio or video clip etc.

figure.head: Figure One: The View from the Bridge
figure.figDesc: A Whistleresque view showing four or five sailing boats in the foreground, and a series of buoys strung out between them.

media.desc: A 45 minute video clip to be displayed in a window 500 px wide

elementSpec.desc: documents the relationship between an electronic text and the source or sources from which it was derived.

encodingDesc.p: Basic encoding, capturing lexical information only. All hyphenation, punctuation, and variant spellings normalized. No formatting or layout information preserved.

elementSpec.desc: describes in detail the aim or purpose for which an electronic file was encoded, together with any other relevant information concerning the process by which it was assembled or collected.

projectDesc.p: Texts collected for use in the Claremont Shakespeare Clinic, June 1990

elementSpec.desc: provides details of editorial principles and practices applied during the encoding of a text.

correction.p: No correction of source texts was performed.

normalization.p: Text has not been normalised, except for spacing.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenation has not been altered with respect to the source files.

quotation.p: Quotation marks have been left in the text and are not explicitly marked up.

segmentation.p: The texts are segmented into utterances (contributions) and segments (corresponding to paragraphs in the source transcription).

elementSpec.desc: states how and under what circumstances corrections have been made in the text.

correction.p: No correction of source texts was performed.

elementSpec.desc: indicates the extent of normalization or regularization of the original source carried out in converting it to electronic form.

normalization.p: Where both upper- and lower-case i, j, u, v, and vv have been normalized, to modern 20th century typographical practice, the choice element has been used to enclose orig and reg elements giving the original and new values respectively. ...
Spacing between words and following punctuation has been regularized to zero spaces; spacing between words has been regularized to one space.
Spelling converted throughout to Modern American usage, based on Websters 9th Collegiate dictionary.

elementSpec.desc: summarizes the way in which hyphenation in a source text has been treated in an encoded version of it.

hyphenation.p: End-of-line hyphenation silently removed where appropriate

elementSpec.desc: specifies editorial practice adopted with respect to quotation marks in the original.

quotation.p:
No quotation marks have been retained. Instead, the rend attribute on the q element is used to specify what kinds of quotation mark was used, according to the following list: dq
double quotes, open and close sq
single quotes, open and close dash
long dash open, no close dg
double guillemets, open and close
All quotation marks are retained in the text and are represented by appropriate Unicode characters.

elementSpec.desc: describes the principles according to which the text has been segmented, for example into sentences, tone-units, graphemic strata, etc.

segmentation.p: s elements mark orthographic sentences and are numbered sequentially within their parent div element

egXML.p: seg elements are used to mark functional constituents of various types within each s; the typology used is defined by a taxonomy element in the corpus header classDecl

elementSpec.desc: provides detailed information about the tagging applied to a document.

exemplum.p: If the partial attribute were not specified here, the implication would be that the document in question contains only hi, title, and para elements.

elementSpec.desc: supplies the formal name of the namespace to which the elements documented by its children belong.

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used only to mark English words italicized in the copy text

elementSpec.desc: documents the usage of a specific element within a specified document.

attDef.desc: specifies the name (generic identifier) of the element indicated by the tag, within the namespace indicated by the parent namespace element. All descendats of text element and text element counts has to be included.

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark English words italicized in the copy text.
Used to mark non-English words in the copy text.

elementSpec.desc: contains one or more taxonomies defining any classificatory codes used elsewhere in the text.
defines a typology either implicitly, by means of a bibliographic citation, or explicitly by a structured taxonomy.

lg.l: Shall I compare thee to a summer's day

elementSpec.desc: contains an individual descriptive category, possibly nested within a superordinate category, within a user-defined taxonomy.

category.catDesc: Session: A parliamentary year, which always begins on the first Tuesday in October at 12.00 o’clock noon and ends on the same date at the same time the following year. However, parliamentary work at Christiansborg is organised in such a way that it primarily takes place from October to June.

elementSpec.desc: describes some category within a taxonomy or text typology, either in the form of a brief prose description or in terms of the situational parameters used by the TEI formal textDesc.
contains a list of definitions of prefixing schemes used in teidata.pointer values, showing how abbreviated URIs using each scheme may be expanded into full URIs.

exemplum.p: In this example, two private URI scheme prefixes are defined and patterns are provided for dereferencing them. Each prefix is also supplied with a human-readable explanation in a p element.

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the psn prefix are pointers to person elements in the personography.xml file. For example, psn:MDH dereferences to personography.xml#MDH.
Private URIs using the bibl prefix can be expanded to form URIs which retrieve the relevant bibliographical reference from www.example.com.

elementSpec.desc: defines a prefixing scheme used in teidata.pointer values, showing how abbreviated URIs using the scheme may be expanded into full URIs.

remarks.p: Using TEI-defined XPointer schemes is not allowed.

prefixDef.p: In the context of this project, private URIs with the prefix "ref" point to div elements in the project's global references.xml file.

elementSpec.desc: records information about an application which has edited the TEI file.

application.label: Stanford CoreNLP
application.desc: Tokenisation, POS tagging, NER and dependency parsed using Stanford CoreNLP https://stanfordnlp.github.io/CoreNLP/.

application.label: NER system for South Slavic languages

elementSpec.desc: provides information about an application which has acted upon the document.

application.label: Stanza
application.desc: Stanza: a jointly trained neural tagger, lemmatizer and dependency parser. Pretrained model based on the italian-isdt-ud-2.5 treebank

application.label: T2K
application.desc: T2K: contains a named entity recognition module for Italian.

application.label: CoNLL-U 2 TEI XML
application.desc: CoNLL-U 2 TEI XML: converter from CoNLL-U format to (ParlaClarin/ParlaMint) Tei XML Format

application.label: Stanford CoreNLP
application.desc: Tokenisation, POS tagging, NER and dependency parsed using Stanford CoreNLP https://stanfordnlp.github.io/CoreNLP/.

elementSpec.desc: contains any label or heading used to identify part of a text, typically but not exclusively in a list or glossary.

exemplum.p: Labels are commonly used for the headwords in glossary lists; note the use of the global xml:lang attribute to set the default language of the glossary list to Middle English, and identify the glosses and headings as modern English or Latin:

list.head: Vocabulary
list.label: nu
lhude
bloweth
med
wude
awe
lhouth
sterteth
list.item: bounds, frisks (cf. Chaucer, K.T.644 a courser, stertingas the fyr
list.label: verteth
murie
swik
naver

exemplum.p: Labels may also be used to record explicitly the numbers or letters which mark list items in ordered lists, as in this extract from Gibbon's Autobiography. In this usage the label element is synonymous with the n attribute on the item element:
exemplum.egXML:
I will add two facts, which have seldom occurred in the composition of six, or at least of five quartos. (1)
My first rough manuscript, without any intermediate copy, has been sent to the press. (2)
Not a sheet has been seen by any human eyes, excepting those of the author and the printer: the faults and the merits are exclusively my own.

exemplum.p: Labels may also be used for other structured list items, as in this extract from the journal of Edward Gibbon:

list.label: March 1757.
list.item: I wrote some critical observations upon Plautus.
list.label: March 8th.
list.item: I wrote a long dissertation upon some lines of Virgil.
list.label: June.
list.item: I saw Mademoiselle Curchod — Omnia vincit amor, et nos cedamus amori.
list.label: August.
list.item: I went to Crassy, and staid two days.

exemplum.p: Note that the label might also appear within the item rather than as its sibling. Though syntactically valid, this usage is not recommended TEI practice.

Labels may also be used to represent a label or heading attached to a paragraph or sequence of paragraphs not treated as a structural division, or to a group of verse lines. Note that, in this case, the label element appears within the p or lg element, rather than as a preceding sibling of it.

egXML.p:
[...]
& n’entrer en mauuais & mal-heu-
ré meſnage. Or des que le conſente-
ment des parties y eſt le mariage eſt
arreſté, quoy que de faict il ne ſoit Puiſſance maritale entre les Romains.
conſommé. Depuis la conſomma-
tion du mariage la femme eſt ſoubs
la puiſſance du mary, s’il n’eſt eſcla-
ue ou enfant de famille : car en ce
cas, la femme, qui a eſpouſé vn en-
fant de famille, eſt ſous la puiſſance [...]

exemplum.p: In this example the text of the label appears in the right hand margin of the original source, next to the paragraph it describes, but approximately in the middle of it.
If so desired the type attribute may be used to distinguish different categories of label.

elementSpec.desc: provides a detailed description of non-bibliographic aspects of a text, specifically the languages and sublanguages used, the situation in which it was produced, the participants and their setting.
describes the setting or settings within which a language interaction takes place, or other places otherwise referred to in a text, edition, or metadata.

settingDesc.p: Texts recorded in the Canadian Parliament building in Ottawa, between April and November 1988

elementSpec.desc: describes one particular setting in which a language interaction takes place.
groups information which describes the nature or topic of a text in terms of a standard classification scheme, thesaurus, etc.
specifies one or more defined categories within some taxonomy or text typology.
describes the identifiable speakers, voices, or other participants in any kind of text or other persons named or otherwise referred to in a text, edition, or metadata.

org.orgName: Lietuvos valstiečių ir žaliųjų sąjungos frakcija
Faction of the Lithuanian Farmers and Greens Union

exemplum.p: This example shows both a very simple person description, and a very detailed one, using some of the more specialized elements from the module for Names and Dates.

elementSpec.desc: contains a list of elements, each of which provides information about an identifiable organization.
contains any type of heading, for example the title of a section, or the heading of a list, glossary, manuscript description, etc.

exemplum.p: The most common use for the head element is to mark the headings of sections. In older writings, the headings or incipits may be rather longer than usual in modern works. If a section has an explicit ending as well as a heading, it should be marked as a trailer, as in this example:

div1.head: In the name of Christ here begins the first book of the ecclesiastical history of Georgius Florentinus, known as Gregory, Bishop of Tours.

div2.head: In the name of Christ here begins Book I of the history.
div2.p: From the Passion of our Lord until the death of Saint Martin four hundred and twelve years passed.
div2.trailer: Here ends the first Book, which covers five thousand, five hundred and ninety-six years from the beginning of the world down to the death of Saint Martin.

exemplum.p: When headings are not inline with the running text (see e.g. the heading "Secunda conclusio") they might however be encoded as if. The actual placement in the source document can be captured with the place attribute.

div.head: Secunda conclusio
div.p:
Potencia: habitus: et actus: recipiunt speciem ab obiectis.
Probatur sic. Omne importans necessariam habitudinem ad proprium [...]

exemplum.p: The head element is also used to mark headings of other units, such as lists:
exemplum.egXML:
With a few exceptions, connectives are equally useful in all kinds of discourse: description, narration, exposition, argument.
Connectives
above
accordingly
across from
adjacent to
again

elementSpec.desc: provides information about an identifiable organization such as a business, a tribe, or any other grouping of people.

org.orgName: The Board of Directors of the General Health Insurance Company of the Czech Republic

elementSpec.desc: contains data relating to any kind of significant event associated with a person, place, or organization.

event.label: Fifty-fifth Parliament of the United Kingdom

org.orgName: Government of the Republic of Croatia

elementSpec.desc: contains a list of descriptions, each of which provides information about an identifiable event.

event.label: 11. vlada Republike Slovenije (20. marec 2013 - 18. september 2014)
11th Government of the Republic of Slovenia (20 March 2013 - 18 September 2014)
14. vlada Republike Slovenije (13. marec 2020 - danes)
14th Government of the Republic of Slovenia (March 13, 2020 - today)

org.orgName: Senate of the Republic of Italy

elementSpec.desc: provides information about relationships identified amongst people, places, and organizations, either informally as prose or as formally expressed relation links.

exemplum.p: The persons with identifiers pp1 and pp2 are the parents of pp3 and pp4; they are also married to each other; pp1 is the employer of pp3, pp5, pp6, and pp7.
The persons with identifiers en_pp1 and en_pp2 live in en_pl1.

listRelation.p: All speakers are members of the Ceruli family, born in Naples.

elementSpec.desc: describes any kind of relationship or linkage amongst a specified group of places, events, persons, objects or other items.

exemplum.p: This indicates that the person with identifier p1 is supervisor of persons p2, p3, and p4.
This indicates that p2, p3, and p4 are all friends.
This indicates that there is a relation, defined by CIDOC CRM, between two resources identified by URLs.

This example records a relationship, defined by the SAWS ontology, between a passage of text identified by a CTS URN, and a variant passage of text in the Perseus Digital Library, and assigns the identification of the relationship to a particular editor (all using resolvable URIs).

elementSpec.desc: contains a list of descriptions, each of which provides information about an identifiable person or a group of people, for example the participants in a language interaction, or the people referred to in a historical source.
provides information about an identifiable individual, for example a participant in a language interaction, or a person referred to in a historical source.

person.p: Female respondent, well-educated, born in Shropshire UK, 12 Jan 1950, of unknown occupation. Speaks French fluently. Socio-Economic status B2.

elementSpec.desc: specifies the sex of a person.
contains information about a person's birth, such as its date and place.
contains information about a person's death, such as its date and place.
contains an absolute or relative place name.
contains an informal description of a person's present or past affiliation with some organization, for example an employer or sponsor.

egXML.p: The affiliation element can also include an ana attribute, which points to the appropriate legislative period when the person was affiliated with the specified organisation.

remarks.p:
Affiliation to organization can be done in three ways (sorted from most concrete - the best solution):
ref
key
text value

elementSpec.desc: contains an informal description of a person's trade, profession or occupation.
contains a description of the educational experience of a person.

egXML.education: Anthony Hammond smuggled her into the University of Cambridge, where she was disguised as his male cousin, Jack. She remained there for some months learning grammar, logic, rhetoric, and ethics

elementSpec.desc: groups elements representing or containing graphic information such as an illustration, formula, or figure.

figure.head: The View from the Bridge
figure.figDesc: A Whistleresque view showing four or five sailing boats in the foreground, and a series of buoys strung out between them.

elementSpec.desc: indicates the location of a graphic or illustration, either forming part of a text, or providing an image of it.

figure.head: Figure One: The View from the Bridge
figure.figDesc: A Whistleresque view showing four or five sailing boats in the foreground, and a series of buoys strung out between them.

elementSpec.desc: describes the languages, sublanguages, registers, dialects, etc. represented within a text.
characterizes a single language or sublanguage used within a text.
summarizes the revision history for a file.
documents a change or set of changes made during the production of a source document, or during the revision of an electronic file.

revisionDesc.change: Tommaso Agnoloni: Generated corpus in ParlaMint.
